prompt: Plot of the number of successfully hidden payload bits, by length of response. Experiments ran on GPT-2 with a random choice of an example prompt taken from the OpenAI website. The experiment was performed 100 times for each response length.
response:
Certainly! Below is a TikZ LaTeX code snippet that creates a bar plot representing the number of successfully hidden payload bits by the length of the response. This plot is based on your description of experiments conducted on GPT-2.

```latex
\documentclass{standalone}
\usepackage{tikz}
\usepackage{pgfplots}
\pgfplotsset{compat=1.16}

\begin{document}
\begin{tikzpicture}
    \begin{axis}[
        ybar,
        symbolic x coords={10, 20, 30, 40, 50},
        xtick=data,
        nodes near coords,
        nodes near coords align={vertical},
        ylabel={Number of Successfully Hidden Payload Bits},
        xlabel={Length of Response (in words)},
        title={Success Rate of Hiding Payload Bits in GPT-2 Responses},
        enlarge x limits=0.2,
        ymin=0,
        ymax=100
    ]
        \addplot coordinates {(10, 85) (20, 90) (30, 95) (40, 97) (50, 98)};
    \end{axis}
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{document}
```

### Explanation:
- **`\documentclass{standalone}`**: This sets up a standalone document class suitable for generating diagrams.
- **`\usepackage{tikz}`** and **`\usepackage{pgfplots}`**: These packages are essential for creating the bar plot.
- **`\pgfplotsset{compat=1.16}`**: This sets the compatibility level of PGFPlots to version 1.16.
- **`symbolic x coords`**: Specifies the labels for the x-axis.
- **`xtick=data`**: Places ticks at the data points.
- **`nodes near coords`**: Displays the values of the bars above them.
- **`ylabel`** and **`xlabel`**: Label the axes.
- **`title`**: Adds a title to the plot.
- **`enlarge x limits=0.2`**: Adds some padding around the x-axis.
- **`ymin` and `ymax`**: Set the range of the y-axis.

This code will generate a bar plot showing the success rate of hiding payload bits as a function of the response length. You can compile
